tossups.answer: The Life of Gargantua and Pantagruel [or Gargantua et Pantagruel; or La vie de Gargantua et de Pantagruel]

parts: Name this word, which controversially appeared on the 1996 New Zealand census. This Māori ("mah-oh-ree") word is used to refer to New Zealanders of European descent.

Māori also refer to Europeans as Tangata tiriti, which translates as "people of the Treaty". The "treaty" in question refers to this 1840 one, in which the Māori ceded their land rights to the English crown.
This Dutch Pākehā ("pah-hay-kah") and explorer was one of the first Europeans to make contact with the Māori. This man names the island state of Australia with capital at Hobart.

answers: Pathetique Symphony in B Minor, Op. 74 [or Tchaikovsky's Symphony No. 6; accept answers indicating the sixth symphony of Pyotr Illyich Tchaikovsky]
parts: What symphony includes a 5/4 "limping waltz" in its second movement? A bassoon plays a solo marked with a dynamic marking of six p in its first movement.

Though Tchaikovsky died nine days after premiering Pathetique, his last composition was an E minor piece in this genre. Tchaikovsky wrote three pieces in this genre for solo keyboard player and orchestra.
A year before dying, Tchaikovsky recommended this Russian for main conductor of Maly Theatre. He is best known for his folksong-laden Symphony No. 1 in G minor.

answers: Soledades [or Soledades, Galerias, y otros poemas; or Solitudes, Galleries, and Other Poems]
Generation of '98 [or Generation of 1898; or Generación del 98; or Generación de 1898]
Spanish Golden Age [or Golden Century; or Siglo de Oro]
parts: Name this Antonio Machado collection which contains "The Traveler" and other poems. It shares its title with an earlier collection by Luis de Góngora ("GOHN-goh-rah").
Machado was part of this modernist literary movement whose other members included Miguel de Unamuno. It formed partly in reaction to Spain's defeat by the U.S.
Much of the work of the "Generation of '98" was inspired by the literature from this period of the 16th and 17th centuries, during which Spanish arts and culture flourished.

answers: Evo Morales [or Juan Evo Morales Ayma]
parts: Name this South American country. The U.S. imposed visa sanctions on this country in July 2020 after David Granger refused to concede to Irfaan Ali in that election.

Pressure from this inter-governmental organization in the Americas was key in getting Granger to concede. This organization, which today mainly focuses on election monitoring, suspended Honduras for two years after the 2009 coup against Manuel Zelaya.
The OAS backed the 2019 ouster of this former Bolivian president on allegations of election fraud, which later independent investigations found to be largely false.
Name these cells that regulate the opening and closing of stomata.
In dicots, stomata are abundant on the underside of these structures. Their top sides are typically flat to maximize surface area for photosynthesis.

In developmental plant biology, the upper and undersides of a leaf are also described by these two words, indicating whether they face toward or away from the stem. They're basically botanical analogues of dorsal and ventral.

answers: Lindbergh baby kidnapping [accept descriptions involving Charles and Anne Lindbergh's baby being kidnapped]
parts: Name this sensational journalist of the 1930s, who was hired by the New York Daily Mirror to write the first-ever syndicated gossip column. He would often coin catchy nicknames for his enemies.

Winchell and Damon Runyon covered the trial for this crime, which H. L. Mencken referred to as "the biggest story since the Resurrection." A reconstructed ladder helped to prove that Bruno Hauptmann ("brew-no hop-men") committed this crime.
Winchell allegedly negotiated the surrender of mobster Louis Buchalter ("buck-halter") to this person, who was the first director of the FBI.
Name these objects that must be made of a single piece of unalloyed metal and have a value of at least one prutah.
The groom gives the ring to the bride under this structure central to the wedding, which represents the home that they'll share.
This document is read out loud under the chuppah. This Aramaic-language contract, which is now purely ceremonial and not legally enforceable, states the groom's obligations to the bride.

answers: Christo Vladimirov Javacheff AND Jeanne-Claude Denat de Guillebon [prompt on partial answers]
parts: In 2008, the Danish-Icelandic artist Olafur Eliasson ("oh-lah-foor el-EE-ah-son") recreated what sort of natural feature underneath Brooklyn Bridge?
In 2008, Eliasson ("el-EE-ah-son") surpassed this couple's installations of orange gates in Central Park as the most-expensive public arts project. This couple also wrapped the Reichstag in plastic.

In 2018, Eliasson ("el-EE-ah-son") installed blocks of ice in this city to showcase the negative effects of climate change. Eliasson ("el-EE-ah-son") also created The Weather Project for this city's Tate Modern museum.

answers: equivalence principle [accept the weak equivalence principle or Einstein equivalence principle]
parts: Name this substance, whose constituent particles have the opposite charges of normal particles.

Collisions between protons and antiprotons were used to discover the top quark by this accelerator at Fermilab, the most powerful in the world before the Large Hadron Collider. Its name indicates that it was the first device to reach tera-electron-volt energies.
The GBAR experiment is using antihydrogen to precisely test this statement, which was previously tested in an 1885 experiment involving a torsion balance.

answers: To Be Young, Gifted, and Black
parts: Name this character who dreams of being a doctor. To her family's disapproval, she prefers the Nigerian suitor Joseph Asagai over the much older, assimilated George Murchison.
Beneatha Younger is considered a semi-autobiographical portrayal of this author and appears in her play A Raisin in the Sun.

After her death at age 34 from pancreatic cancer, Hansberry's writings were adapted into this play by her ex-husband Robert Nemiroff. This play shares its title with a song that Nina Simone wrote in memory of Hansberry.
Name this formulator of a paradox about the contradiction between lack of evidence for extraterrestrial life and the estimated probability of their existence.
This first space probe to leave the Solar System contained a plaque including basic info about Earth and humans that was to serve as a message from mankind to extraterrestrial life.
In 2015, Stephen Hawking announced this most comprehensive SETI effort to date to search a million nearby stars and 100 galaxies for radio and laser transmissions.

answers: "Battle Royal" [accept Chapter 1 of Invisible Man or the first chapter of Invisible Man]
parts: Identify this scene in which the narrator jumps onto an electrified carpet to retrieve gold coins after he and his friends are blindfolded. You may also give the chapter number and the novel which it is found in.
The "Battle Royal" scene opens this African-American author's novel Invisible Man.

Before the "Battle Royal," the unnamed narrator observes a dancing woman with one of these objects tattooed on her belly. In a discussion about choosing one for The Brotherhood, Brother Westrum says "everybody wants" one of these objects.

answers: Flower Garland Sutra [or Flower Ornament Sutra; or Flower Adornment Sutra; or Avatamsaka Sutra; or Huayan Jing; or Kegon Kyou; or Hwaeom Gyeong; or Hoa Nghiêm Kinh; or Mahavaipulya Buddhavatamsaka Sutra; or Dafangguang Fohuayan Jing; or Daihoukou Butsukegon Kyou; or Daebanggwang Bulhwaeom Gyeong; or Dai Phuong Quang Phât Hoa Nghiêm Kinh]
emptiness [or empty; or voidness; or hollowness; accept nothingness; or kong; or kuu; or gong; or không]
Zen [or Chan; or Seon; or Thiên]
parts: Name this long sutra that describes the fractal view of the universe seen by the Buddhas, who manifest in every atom. Its title object represents the glory of the Buddhas' understanding of the true nature of reality.

The Buddhas' view of the universe comes from knowing that all phenomena have this property that causes them to infinitely interpenetrate. The Heart Sutra equates form and this property, which in Sanskrit is called shunyata ("SHOON-yuh-tah").
The Flower Garland School's doctrines heavily influenced the development of this other Mahayana school focused on meditation and emptiness.

answers: Prince Shotoku [or Prince Umayado; or Prince Kamitsumiya]
parts: Give this Japanese word which became Japan's official name late in the 7th century. It loosely translates as "sun origin," giving rise to the epithet "Land of the Rising Sun".
In correspondence with Emperor Yang of Sui, this prince encouraged him to call Japan by Nihon. Through the Seventeen-Article Constitution, he promoted Buddhism as Japan's state religion.
Worship of Prince Shotoku peaked with the creation of the Shoko mandara during this period, which began after the defeat of the Taira clan at the Battle of Dan-no-ura.

answers: The Wretched of the Earth [or Les Damnés de la Terre]
parts: Name this Cameroonian author of On the Postcolony, who coined the term "necropolitics" to describe the use of power to dictate whether people live or die.
Mbembe's "necropolitics" is a development of this French philosopher's concepts of "biopolitics" and "biopower," which are defined in his book The History of Sexuality.
Mbembe's work also draws on this 1961 book by Frantz Fanon, which argues that revolutionary colonial subjects exemplify the lumpenproletariat of Marxist theory.

answers: (Julius Wilhelm) Richard Dedekind [accept Dedekind zeta functions or Dedekind eta function]
prime [accept word forms like primality or primes; accept prime ideals, prime numbers, or prime factorization]
parts: Name the coefficient of the -1 term in a meromorphic function's Laurent series.

The class number formula gives in arithmetic (“arithMETic”) terms the residue at 1 of this man's zeta functions, which generalize Riemann's to number fields. His zeta function is a weight 1/2 modular form whose 24th power times a constant is the modular discriminant.
Dedekind zeta functions have an Euler product over ideals with this property. Each of the integers has a unique "factorization" into a product of these numbers.

answers: Benedictines [or Order of Saint Benedict; or O.S.B.]
Innocent III [or Lotario dei Conti di Segni; or Lothar of Segni; prompt on Innocent]
Paracelsus [or Philippus Aureolus Theophrastus Bombastus von Hohenheim]
parts: Perhaps the biggest provider of health care in the Middle Ages was this monastic order, founded by a saint from Nursia. They are known for wearing black habits.

The Hospital of the Holy Spirit, Europe's oldest hospital, was founded with efforts from this pope. He decreed a crusade that was assisted by Enrico Dandolo in his bull Post miserabile ("mee-seh-RAH-bee-lay").

Medicine improved with this Swiss scientist's discovery of laudanum, which was used as an anesthetic until the 19th century. He also published one of the earliest tracts on surgery, The Great Surgery Book.

answers: territories [accept territorialization or reterritorialization or deterritorialization; accept the map is not the territory]
parts: The first of the volume's two books is titled for, and offers a critique of, the Freudian "complex" named for this man who had sex with his mother Jocasta.

The volume uses a verb referring to these places to describe the process in which capitalism separates material flows from their origins. An oft-cited quote claims "the map" is not one of these places.
The volume borrows this term from botany to describe deterritorialized networks with no beginning or end, and structures its book A Thousand Plateaus as one of them.
Name this form of intricate writing. Arabic examples are done on a variety of mediums using a dried reed pen, while Chinese examples typically use a brush.
In Turkish mosques, many of these spaces - which are named for their half-moon shape and are often found above archways - contain calligraphic verses from the Qur'an.
Many lunettes were done in this Turkish style of tiling that combined Ottoman and Chinese patterns. This style, named for a town in western Anatolia, was often used in the buildings of Mimar Sinan.

answers: shipwrecks [or shipwrecking; accept naufragar or naufragio or naufrage; accept answers which refer to being shipwrecked; prompt on wrecking or drowning or deaths]
parts: Name this Italian Romantic poet of "To Silvia" who wrote "This solitary hill has always been dear to me" to begin the poem "The Infinite".
"The Infinite" is one of these fourteen-line poems, which were pioneered by the earlier Italian author Petrarch.

The speaker of "The Infinite" concludes by saying that one of these events would be "sweet to me". Stéphane Mallarmé's poem "A Throw of the Dice Will Never Abolish Chance" begins by pondering the "eternal circumstance" of the aftermath of these events.
